head.title: If the Shoe Doesn't Fit, Why Wear It?

hedline.hl1: If the Shoe Doesn't Fit, Why Wear It?

abstract.p: Letter from Helene Benardo says misogynist shoe designers will change only when women refuse to buy their killing, crushing instruments of torture

block.p: Although I agree wholeheartedly with Deborah L. Rhode (Op-Ed, Oct. 18), I must speak as one who was liberated from high heel shoes many years ago. The issue is twofold: not that there are no attractive shoes out there (there are), but of far greater importance is the old economic principle of supply and demand.

Although I agree wholeheartedly with Deborah L. Rhode (Op-Ed, Oct. 18), I must speak as one who was liberated from high heel shoes many years ago. The issue is twofold: not that there are no attractive shoes out there (there are), but of far greater importance is the old economic principle of supply and demand.
If the misogynist designers and manufacturers see that women will not buy their killing, crushing instruments of torture, then, and only then, will they be forced to change.
